title: Can I write one essay and turn it in to two different classes? - Quora

response.answer_text: When I was in my doctoral program I was told to build synergies between my papers. Using this as my benchmark I would say you are short changing yourself UNLESS you make meaningful changes or tweaks to one of the two papers. Can you take an opposing view? Can you change the underlying assumptions inherent in your work? You are in school to grow and develop as a person, not to simply graduate. While you can turn in the same essay for two classes, how is doing that contributing to your intellectual development? Don't take the lazy way out, challenge yourself.

It may be fine with your teachers - but what is your school’s self-plagiarism policy? At my high school, all of our assignments were run through a plagiarism checker. If I'd turned one paper in to a teacher, who ran the checker, and then the same paper in to another teacher, my paper would have been flagged as plagiarized. Even if it's okay with your teachers, I'd recommend looking into your school’s policy. You'll find that often teachers don't get the last say in these matters.

It’s unusual for a teacher to permit that. (Why should you be granted credit twice for the same work? That hardly seems fair.) This alone makes it a risky move for you. You would be well advised to be very sure you’ve understood them correctly. At the university level, you may well find that this is prohibited entirely, regardless of what the professor says.

I was a student of language in college, and I was required to write a paper for English, Spanish, and French every week. I would start a paper in one language and translate it into the others. It was a wonderful experience because I could see the nuances between these languages and how the attempt to say the same thing in each one could go a bit sideways. Of course, the slight deviations did not really matter. I had a fine paper to turn into each class.

If both teachers say you can, you don’t need anyone else’s permission. Go ahead. But if you want to do outstanding, and not merely acceptable work, try reading two different articles with very different perspectives on the same event. Explore each in depth emphasizing one point of view as primary, and you’ll be able to discuss it a lot better.

Yes, provided that you disclose this to your teachers and they accept it. In my senior year of High School, I did a research paper on the military tactics of the Napoleonic wars and their origins in the pre-revoloutionary period tactical developments. I submitted this for credit in French (as some of the sources were in French), History, and English (research paper special unit). Yes a three-in-one. Go for it.

If your teachers use a database to check for plagiarism, the second submission will be flagged for “self-plagiarism.” Yes, it is sometimes against the rules to copy yourself. Be careful, and hey, you might learn more if you do two unique pieces of work.
If it’s okay with your teachers, it’s fine. It will be interesting to compare their marks and comments!
